title: Vector Equation of a Line Quiz
description: Test your understanding of vector equations of lines.

questions.question: What is the vector equation of a line?
questions.explanation: The vector equation is r = a + t b, where a is a point on the line and b is the direction vector.

questions.question: In the equation r = a + t b, what does 't' represent?
questions.explanation: t is a scalar parameter that varies to give different points on the line.

questions.question: How do you find the direction vector between two points?
questions.explanation: Direction vector b = B - A, where A and B are position vectors of points on the line.

questions.question: Two lines are parallel if:
questions.explanation: Parallel lines have direction vectors that are scalar multiples of each other.

questions.question: The parametric equations corresponding to r = (1,2,3) + t(2,3,4) are:
questions.explanation: Each coordinate is the corresponding component of the position vector plus t times the direction component.
